content:
This solved the problem for another person:

Access your mail through the webmail interface. In the webmail page, go to preferences > mail. Near the bottom of the page is a section for "Access from other mail clients". Check "enable POP access".

My wild guess is that Rogers made a change after they bought Shaw.

Does that fix the problem?
creator: mozilla98

content:
Thanks for your reply. That is how my configuration is set. Apparently Shaw/Rogers is having an internet issue and others clients are having problems. I was told to try again tomorrow. 

I hope Shaw/Rogers gets their act together soon.

content:
@Ed: Thank you for the response. I found it.

IMO, this change is inconvenient. I used to be able to compact all folders no matter what folder was active. Now I have to select the one account name.

Compacting all folders is my usual use case. In the rare instance of wanting to compact an individual folder, there was always the right-click option.

In the current method, does the compact all folders choice compact for all email accounts or only the selected account?
creator: hspindel

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content: More information may help. the active profile prior to update should still be available. Click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles', then see if more than one profile is shown. Launch and see if your data are there. Regarding the backup, I suggest viewing the backup via Windows File Explorer to verify that the missing folders are there, as sometimes a backup is itself incomplete.
creator: davidsk

content: Are these spam reports prepared by your email provider? That might indicate the suspected emails are being withheld at the server as a service to you. Possibly, a screenshot of a spam report may clarify that.

content: This follows my interpretation. That doesn't come from Thunderbird, but from 1und1.de, which is likely your internet/email provider. content: This can happen if you are using an addon that assists in grammar, or if you are using a grammar support product externally from Thunderbird.

content: if it is thunderbird, it will show a line under the word. you can rightclick and select 'add to dictionary' and 'ronnie' won't be flagged again. But your screenshot does look like something else is there. Please check your addons and I would also shut down the browser to remove that as a possibility.

content:
Do you mean that "primary password" that controls access to your e-mail account passwords?

Or do you mean an e-mail account password?

In most cases, people mean an account password, which must be re-set with the e-mail service provider. Thunderbird does not control passwords for e-mail accounts.
creator: mozilla98

content: Try this: - click settings>privacy&security - click savedpasswords and then showpasswords - if you see an entry for the SMTP server, click to edit the password and enter it there. -
creator: davidsk

content:
Briony, there are two places in account settings to change the username associated with an outgoing server. Did you find them and try them?

  1. Click on account name > edit SMTP server
  2. Click on Outgoing server (SMTP) in the left pane > select the server > edit
creator: mozilla98
